partial_orders.reason: Edit 0 imports PRECISION_HALVES and PRECISION_TENTHS constants, while Edit 1 uses these exact same constants in the changed lines. The import creates the symbols that are immediately needed by the usage in Edit 1. This is a classic import-usage relationship where both edits reference the exact same symbols (PRECISION_HALVES and PRECISION_TENTHS). In Python, the usage can be written before the import (it would only fail at runtime), so either edit can be staged first, making this bi-directional.

Edit 0 imports PRECISION_HALVES and PRECISION_TENTHS constants, while Edit 1 uses these exact same constants in the changed lines. The import creates the symbols that are immediately needed by the usage in Edit 1. This is a classic import-usage relationship where both edits reference the exact same symbols (PRECISION_HALVES and PRECISION_TENTHS). In Python, the usage can be written before the import (it would only fail at runtime), so either edit can be staged first, making this bi-directional.

These edits are part of a single refactoring of the display_temp function that changes the control flow from multiple return statements to a single return statement. Edit 0 replaces magic numbers (0.5, 0.1) with named constants and changes the return statements to assignments. Edit 1 completes this refactoring by converting the final return statement to an else clause with assignment, and adds the single return statement at the end. Both edits modify the same function and the same temperature variable, creating a mechanically obvious sequence where after making either edit, the other becomes the immediate next step to complete the consistent refactoring pattern. The changes are structurally dependent - edit 0 establishes the pattern of assigning to temperature instead of returning, and edit 1 completes this pattern for the final case.
